raw_text: For parsing, we mapped all unknown words to unknown word symbols, and applied the Viterbi algorithm as implemented in Schmid (2004), exploiting its ability to deal with highly-ambiguous grammars
clean_text: For parsing, we mapped all unknown words to unknown word symbols, and applied the Viterbi algorithm as implemented in Schmid (2004), exploiting its ability to deal with highly-ambiguous grammars.

citing_paper_authors: Fabienne, Braune | Nina, Seemann | Daniel, Quernheim | Andreas, Maletti
raw_text: The starred results are statistically significant improvements over the Baseline (at confidence p < 0.05) .English side of the bilingual data was parsed using the Charniak parser of Charniak and Johnson (2005), and the German side was parsed using BitPar (Schmid, 2004) without the function and morphological annotations
clean_text: The starred results are statistically significant improvements over the Baseline (at confidence p > 0.05). English side of the bilingual data was parsed using the Charniak parser of Charniak and Johnson (2005), and the German side was parsed using BitPar (Schmid, 2004) without the function and morphological annotations.

citing_paper_authors: Fabienne, Cap | Alexander, Fraser | Marion, Weller | Aoife, Cahill
raw_text: The key linguistic knowledge sources that we use are morphological analysis and generation of German based on SMOR, a morphological ana lyzer/generator of German (Schmid et al 2004) and the BitPar parser, which is a state-of-the-art parser of German (Schmid, 2004)
clean_text: The key linguistic knowledge sources that we use are morphological analysis and generation of German based on SMOR, a morphological analyzer/generator of German (Schmid et al 2004) and the BitPar parser, which is a state-of-the-art parser of German (Schmid, 2004).

clean_text: We use a frequency-based notation because we use out of-the-box software Bitpar (Schmid, 2004) which implements inside-outside estimation Bitpar reads in frequency models and converts them to relative frequency models.

raw_text: For our parsing results we use BitPar, a fast and freely available general PCFG parser (Schmid, 2004)
clean_text: For our parsing results we use BitPar, a fast and freely available general PCFG parser (Schmid, 2004).

citing_paper_authors: Beate, Dorow | Florian, Laws | Lukas, Michelbacher | Christian, Scheible | Jason, Utt
raw_text: The German V-O pairs were extracted from a syntactic analysis of the HGC carried out using the BitPar parser (Schmid, 2004) .We used only V-O pairs because they cons ti tute far more sense-discriminative contexts than, for example, verb-subject pairs, but we plan to examine these and other grammatical relationships in future work
clean_text: The German V-O pairs were extracted from a syntactic analysis of the HGC carried out using the BitPar parser (Schmid, 2004). We used only V-O pairs because they cons ti tute far more sense-discriminative contexts than, for example, verb-subject pairs, but we plan to examine these and other grammatical relationships in future work.

raw_text: An existing SCFG parser (Schmid, 2004) was then used, with a simple unknown word heuristic, to generate the Viterbi n-best parses with n= 100, and, after removing the address labels, all equal parses and their probabilities were summed, and the one with highest probability chosen
clean_text: An existing SCFG parser (Schmid, 2004) was then used, with a simple unknown word heuristic, to generate the Viterbi n-best parses with n= 100, and, after removing the address labels, all equal parses and their probabilities were summed, and the one with highest probability chosen.
